text.author: Hawaiʻi State Judiciary
text.summary: In a case before the Supreme Court of the State of Hawaiʻi, attorney Bradley Sova argues that removal of private property from public land is not protected by due process rights based on precedent from Lavan, which states that there is no consistutionally protected right to use public sidewalks for storage, while judges suggest private property enjoys due process regardless.
